title: Apps to turn you into an airbrushed stunner, just stay subtle
text:
Perfect365 will "soften" your skin (read: make it all one colour), "deepen" your smile (give you a manic Julia Roberts look) and add the most enchanting drag queen makeup to your countenance. supplied RuPaul would hit the roof.
Subtle improvements If used subtly, the app is actually pretty wonderful. In two minutes you can delete blemishes, deepen your tan and brighten your eyes and boom, it's you, just airbrushed. But the problem with Perfect365, as I'm sure most of the 60 million users have found out, once you pop you can't stop.
Once you've slimmed your jaw, it's nearly impossible not to then lift your cheeks, dab colour on your lips and swirl some glitter around your eyes. You know?
 While you might be going for "classy" ... getting over-enthusiastic will make you look like Marge Simpson after Homer invented the makeup gun for "the woman who has four-fifths of a second to get ready". Fox Home Entertainment The technology is quite elegant. It takes just seconds for the ArcSoft face detection software to map your eyes, nose, hairline, bone structure and mouth and then apply any changes with laser-like precision to your face.
"Live" application is a new feature and the way the app keeps the modifications in place on your moving, live face is quite stunning. Even if you move about rapidly, the colour and skin tones don't lag behind.
This kind of facial recognition technology has moved rapidly from specific military and intelligence use to the mainstream. It was only a matter of time before the business of narcissism developed uses for it. In fact, identifying unique facial features has spawned plenty of interesting businesses, not least Churchix â€“ a company offering to keep track of Church attendees by identifying faces in each service.
But Perfect365, while it is self-indulgent and fairly dishonest, is a lot of fun. And it took a bit of willpower not to pay the extra $2.49 to unlock new sets of makeup themes: I was itching to see what I looked like painted with "ballroom", "nautical", " St Paddy's" and "naughty".
It took my editor saying sternly, "People will be really disappointed when they meet you in person" for my Kardashian-inspired enthusiasm to abate.
